context: Ancient and medieval Hindu texts identify <a1_0>six<a1_0/> <a0_0>pramāṇas<a0_0/> as correct means of accurate knowledge and truths: <a2_0>pratyakṣa<a2_0/> (<b5_0>perception<b5_0/>), <a3_0>anumāṇa<a3_0/> (inference), upamāṇa (comparison and analogy), arthāpatti (postulation, derivation from circumstances), anupalabdi (non-perception, negative/cognitive proof) and <a4_0>śabda<a4_0/> (word, testimony of past or present reliable experts) Each of these are further categorized in terms of conditionality, completeness, confidence and possibility of error, by each school . The various schools vary on <b6_0>how many of these six are valid paths of knowledge<b6_0/>. For example, the <b9_0>Cārvāka nāstika<b9_0/> philosophy holds that only one (<b7_0>perception<b7_0/>) is an epistemically reliable means of knowledge, the Samkhya school holds three are (perception, inference and testimony), while the <b8_0>Mīmāṃsā and Advaita<b8_0/> schools hold all six are epistemically useful and reliable means to knowledge.
